title: Personal Track Safety
description: Learn essential railway safety procedures, trackside protocols, hazard identification, and emergency responses required for Personal Track Safety certification. This comprehensive module covers all aspects of working safely on and around railway infrastructure.

flashcards.question: What defines being 'on or near the line'?
flashcards.answer: You are on the line itself or within 3 meters (10 foot) of the running line and there are no fences or permanent structures between you and the running line.
flashcards.imageAlt: Person standing near railway tracks with 3-meter distance marked

flashcards.question: What defines being 'on the line side'?
flashcards.answer: Within the boundary fence and the point that is 'on or near the line' and can be seen by approaching drivers.
flashcards.imageAlt: Illustration of the lineside area within boundary fence

flashcards.question: What is a 'position of safety'?
flashcards.answer: When you are at least the minimum required distance away from the passing train at the maximum line speed it is permitted to travel.
flashcards.imageAlt: Person standing at safe distance from tracks

flashcards.question: What is the '4 foot' area?
flashcards.answer: The running line itself.
flashcards.imageAlt: Illustration of the 4 foot area on railway tracks

flashcards.question: What is the '6 foot' area?
flashcards.answer: The space between the 2 running lines.
flashcards.imageAlt: Illustration of the 6 foot area between railway tracks

flashcards.question: What is the '10 foot' area?
flashcards.answer: The space between 2 sets of running lines.
flashcards.imageAlt: Illustration of the 10 foot area between two sets of tracks

flashcards.question: What is the 'cess' area?
flashcards.answer: The space between the running line and the boundary fence.
flashcards.imageAlt: Illustration of the cess area beside railway tracks

flashcards.question: What are the additional risks of reversible and SIMBIDS lines?
flashcards.answer: Trains can be signalled to approach from any direction.
flashcards.imageAlt: Diagram showing trains approaching from multiple directions

flashcards.question: When are you permitted to be on or near the line?
flashcards.answer: If it is part of your duty with signaller's permission, to inspect your train for faults or damage, to lay emergency protection, or when laying assistance protection during a controlled or emergency evacuation.
flashcards.imageAlt: Railway worker with proper safety equipment on tracks

flashcards.question: What should you consider before going on or near the line?
flashcards.answer: Line speeds, direction trains normally approach from, and areas of limited clearance.
flashcards.imageAlt: Railway worker checking safety information before track access

flashcards.question: What protective equipment do you need when on or near the line?
flashcards.answer: Clean high visibility clothing, safety footwear, and hand lamp.
flashcards.imageAlt: Complete set of required protective equipment for track work

flashcards.question: What must you NOT wear when on or near the line?
flashcards.answer: Anything that would affect your vision or ability to hear approaching trains.
flashcards.imageAlt: Examples of prohibited items that impair awareness on tracks

flashcards.question: What does the acronym MAPS stand for when a train approaches?
flashcards.answer:
M - Move to a position of safety
A - Acknowledge approaching train
P - Place any tools down on the floor
S - Stay in a position of safety until train has passed and you are sure no other trains are approaching
flashcards.imageAlt: Illustration of MAPS protocol with worker responding to train

flashcards.question: What must you do if caught between adjacent lines when a train approaches?
flashcards.answer: Lay face down in the 6 foot, 10 foot or CESS (NOT IN THE 4 FOOT), gather any loose clothing underneath you, do not move until train has passed and you are sure no other trains are approaching.
flashcards.imageAlt: Illustration of proper position if caught between lines

flashcards.question: What does a red and white square sign with 'warning limited clearance' indicate?
flashcards.answer: No position of safety for the length of this structure. You must not attempt to pass while a train is approaching.
flashcards.imageAlt: Red and white limited clearance warning sign

flashcards.question: What does a blue and white square sign with 'warning no refuges' indicate?
flashcards.answer: No position of safety for the length of this structure. However, there ARE positions of safety or refuges ON OPPOSITE SIDE OF RAILWAY LINE.
flashcards.imageAlt: Blue and white no refuges warning sign

flashcards.question: What does a prohibition sign with man in red circle with red line through indicate?
flashcards.answer: You must not pass this sign while trains are running. YOU WILL NOT BE ABLE TO REACH A POSITION OF SAFETY. If carrying out emergency protection, take extreme care.

flashcards.question: What is the role of a COSS?
flashcards.answer: A COSS is a Controller of Site Safety. They will set up a safe system of work and are there to ensure everyone's safety.

flashcards.question: How do you identify a COSS?
flashcards.answer: By their BLUE ARMBAND with COSS written in WHITE LETTERS.

flashcards.question: How do you identify a Lookout?
flashcards.answer: By their WHITE ARMBAND with LOOKOUT written in RED LETTERS.
flashcards.imageAlt: Lookout with white and red armband

flashcards.question: How do you identify a Site Warden?
flashcards.answer: By their WHITE ARMBAND with SITE WARDEN written in BLUE LETTERS.
flashcards.imageAlt: Site Warden with white and blue armband

flashcards.question: What are the principles of Red Zone working?
flashcards.answer: Trains are still running. COSS will appoint a 'Lookout' to watch for trains approaching the work area. The 'Lookout' is identified by a white armband with red lettering and carries a blue and white chequered flag and horn.
flashcards.imageAlt: Red Zone working setup with lookout

flashcards.question: What are the principles of Green Zone working?
flashcards.answer: Green Zone working has three types: Safeguarded (all lines blocked), Fenced (barrier between workforce and running line), and Separated (human barrier/Site Warden between workforce and running line).

flashcards.question: What are the requirements for a rigid fence in Green Zone working?
flashcards.answer: For 0-100 mph: 1.25 meters (4 foot) from nearest running line. For 101-125 mph: 2 meters (6 foot 6in). For over 125 mph: no safe distance is possible.

flashcards.question: What are the requirements for tape fencing in Green Zone working?
flashcards.answer: For 0-40 mph: 1.25 meters (4 foot) from nearest running line. For 41-125 mph: 2 meters (6 foot 6in). For over 125 mph: no safe distance is possible.

flashcards.question: What are the requirements for Separated Green Zone working?
flashcards.answer: A Site Warden is appointed by the COSS/SWL to act as a human barrier. There must be 6 feet 6 inches (2 meters) between the site of work and the nearest running line.

flashcards.question: What is a Portal type OHL structure?
flashcards.answer: A structure that spans across multiple tracks with supports on both sides, resembling a portal or gateway.

flashcards.question: What is a Cantilever type OHL structure?
flashcards.answer: A structure with support on one side and an arm (registration arm) extending over the tracks.

flashcards.question: What is a Head span type OHL structure?
flashcards.answer: A structure where wires are suspended between two adjacent masts or structures across the tracks.

flashcards.question: What is the Catenary wire in OHL?
flashcards.answer: The top wire in the overhead line equipment system that supports the contact wire below it.

flashcards.question: What is the Contact wire in OHL?
flashcards.answer: The wire that the pantograph touches to draw electricity.

flashcards.question: What are Droppers in OHL?
flashcards.answer: The vertical wires that connect the catenary wire to the contact wire.

flashcards.question: What is a Head span wire in OHL?
flashcards.answer: The top wire running between 2 adjacent structures.

flashcards.question: What is a Cross span wire in OHL?
flashcards.answer: The lower wire running between 2 adjacent structures.

flashcards.question: What is a Mast or Structure in OHL?
flashcards.answer: The metal pole either side of tracks to which OHL components are attached.

flashcards.question: What is a Structure plate in OHL?
flashcards.answer: An ID plate used to identify the location of overhead wires and structures.

flashcards.question: What are Insulators in OHL?
flashcards.answer: Components used between OHL and structures to ensure the structure is insulated from the 25,000 volts.

flashcards.question: What is a Structure bond in OHL?
flashcards.answer: A component attached to the bottom of the structure and the track to complete the circuit.

flashcards.question: What are Along-Track Conductors?
flashcards.answer: Earth return wires that are part of the OHL system.

flashcards.question: What is a Red bond and what action must be taken if one is found unsecured?
flashcards.answer: A structure bond with red cable. If found unsecured, do not touch and report immediately to the signaller or ECO.

flashcards.question: What is the minimum safe distance that must be maintained from the OHL?
flashcards.answer: 2.75 meters (9 foot)
flashcards.imageAlt: Illustration showing 2.75 meter distance from OHL

flashcards.question: What is the purpose of the orange line at cab roof height?
flashcards.answer: CANT line - cannot go above the line if OHL are still live.
flashcards.imageAlt: Orange CANT line on train cab roof

flashcards.question: How do you get an emergency isolation of overhead power?
flashcards.answer: Contact the signaller or ECO and give the structure plate ID to identify the location.
flashcards.imageAlt: Person using emergency phone to request isolation

flashcards.question: What is a mobile phone usage restriction on the operational railway?
flashcards.answer: Only use in a position of safety, do not become distracted, do not use in an active cab.
flashcards.imageAlt: Proper mobile phone usage in position of safety

flashcards.question: How do you identify a lineside telephone?
flashcards.answer: White background with black cross on it.
flashcards.imageAlt: Lineside telephone with white background and black cross

flashcards.question: How do you identify a signal post telephone?
flashcards.answer: White background with black stripes running diagonally from top right to bottom left.
flashcards.imageAlt: Signal post telephone with diagonal stripes

flashcards.question: What does a lineside or signal post telephone with red/white limited clearance sign indicate?
flashcards.answer: Use your train as protection when using this telephone as there is limited clearance.

flashcards.question: What does a lineside or signal post telephone with yellow circle indicate?
flashcards.answer: Only use in an emergency due to limited clearance.

flashcards.question: What does a signal post telephone with white/yellow diamond with 'X' indicate?
flashcards.answer: Only use in an emergency.
flashcards.imageAlt: Telephone with white/yellow diamond and X

flashcards.question: What does a signal with white diamond and telephone number underneath indicate?
flashcards.answer: No telephone present. Signaller is aware of your presence by track circuit. Use GSMR or mobile phone to contact signaller.
flashcards.imageAlt: Signal with white diamond and telephone number

flashcards.question: On TFL infrastructure, which rails are electrified by DC current and what risks are associated?
flashcards.answer: Third rail is electrified. Do not use track circuit operating clips on TFL infrastructure. There is danger of electrocution if areas near third rail are flooded.

flashcards.question: What environmental conditions will affect ability to undertake duties safely?
flashcards.answer: Poor visibility (darkness, heavy rain, fog, snow), high winds or background noise affecting ability to hear trains, and slippery underfoot conditions caused by ice/snow or rain.

flashcards.question: How frequently should you look up when on or near the line?
flashcards.answer: Every 5 seconds.
flashcards.imageAlt: Worker looking up regularly on track

flashcards.question: For how many seconds should you be in a position of safety prior to a train arriving?
flashcards.answer: 10 seconds before the train arrives.
flashcards.imageAlt: Worker in position of safety as train approaches

flashcards.question: What must you ensure before leaving a position of safety?
flashcards.answer: Ensure the train has passed and no other trains are approaching.
flashcards.imageAlt: Worker checking before leaving position of safety

flashcards.question: When crossing a line, what can and cannot be stepped on?
flashcards.answer: Walk ballast to ballast. Do not step on sleepers, rail, or points.

flashcards.question: Where would you find information about authorised walking routes?
flashcards.answer: In the Health and Safety notice case.

flashcards.question: What information is found on an OHL structure plate ID?
flashcards.answer: Top letter: route. Middle number(s): miles from London or start of route. Bottom number(s): number of structure in that mile.
flashcards.imageAlt: OHL structure plate with ID information

flashcards.question: What is the minimum distance from OHL in an emergency and what additional measures must be taken?
flashcards.answer: 2.75 meters (9 foot). Ensure OHL is isolated before getting any closer. Wear non-conductive, dry clothing if attempting to move anyone in contact with OHL. Do not stand in water. Do not use anything metal near OHL.

flashcards.question: What must you do if granted an emergency isolation and your relief arrives?
flashcards.answer: Contact the ECO, identify yourself, state your relief has arrived, then pass the phone to your relief who will take over the isolation. DO NOT LEAVE BEFORE YOU ARE RELIEVED.

flashcards.question: What actions should be taken if you notice faults with the OHL?
flashcards.answer: Report immediately to the ECO (can be via signaller). Do not go near any faults or anything that may be in contact with the OHL.

flashcards.question: What is the location for the ECO and what is the number?
flashcards.answer: Romford. Internal number 175, external 01708 743545.

flashcards.question: What is the position of safety for line speeds of 110mph?
flashcards.answer: 2 meters (6 foot 6 inches) - applies for speeds 101-125mph.

flashcards.question: What is the position of safety for line speeds of 75mph?
flashcards.answer: 1.25 meters (4 foot) - applies for speeds 0-100mph.

flashcards.question: What is the position of safety for line speeds of 130mph?
flashcards.answer: There is no safe working distance for speeds over 125mph.

flashcards.question: If you cross the line in advance of a level crossing and the gates are open to road traffic, or a signal at danger, is it safe to assume there is no train approaching?
flashcards.answer: No. Barriers could be faulty, a train could have had a SPAD (Signal Passed At Danger), or it could be a runaway train.

flashcards.question: Do trains always approach from the direction they are signalled?
flashcards.answer: No. It could be a train making a wrong direction move, Single line working, a runaway train, or an engineering train in a possession.

flashcards.question: What hazards should you look out for on a passing train?
flashcards.answer: Door(s) open, fire on train, insecure load, headlight not lit, hot axle box, tail light not lit/missing, damage/anything wrapped around pantograph, driver sounding distress horn, hazard warning lights flashing.

flashcards.question: What would you consider dangerous to a passing train?
flashcards.answer: Trespassers, large animals on the track, fire, floods, track defects, obstruction on the line.

flashcards.question: If you came across a lineside fire, what would be your immediate reaction?
flashcards.answer: Report immediately to the signaller.

flashcards.question: If you sighted a trespasser on the railway and were unable to stop your train, what would be your reaction?
flashcards.answer: Report it immediately to the signaller. If on running lines, make an emergency group call.

flashcards.question: What is a 'PICEI' in regard to overhead lines?
flashcards.answer: Person In Charge of Electrical Isolation.

flashcards.question: When protecting the line because of collapse or partial collapse of OHL, what must you be aware of regarding emergency equipment?
flashcards.answer: If any OHL is touching rails, they could also be live. Do not place detonators or track circuit clips on any lines you believe may be in contact with OHL.

flashcards.question: What are the rules for mobile phone use on the operational railway?
flashcards.answer: Only use in an emergency if no other communication is available. Do not allow yourself to become distracted. Stay in a position of safety. In times of disruption when detained on a running line, company mobile phone must be switched on after 5 minutes to enable SDC to pass on messages.
flashcards.imageAlt: Proper mobile phone usage on railway

flashcards.question: What hand signals can be used to stop a train in an emergency?
flashcards.answer: Red flag, red light, any light waved vigorously, or two arms raised straight up in the air.
flashcards.imageAlt: Emergency hand signals to stop train

flashcards.question: When should you place 3 additional detonators when protecting an incident?
flashcards.answer: When a train is approaching, at the entrance to a tunnel, at trailing points from the direction the next train is most likely to approach from, before using a telephone, or before going to speak to a signaller in a signal box.

true-false.statement: When on or near the line, you need to look up only once every 15 seconds.
true-false.explanation: This statement is false. You must look up every 5 seconds when 'on or near the line' to ensure you're aware of any approaching trains.
true-false.imageAlt: Worker looking up on railway tracks

true-false.statement: A position of safety must be reached at least 10 seconds before a train arrives.
true-false.explanation: This statement is true. You must be in a position of safety at least 10 seconds before a train arrives to ensure your safety.
true-false.imageAlt: Person in position of safety as train approaches

true-false.statement: When walking on the operational railway, you should walk in the 4 foot when possible.
true-false.explanation: This statement is false. You should walk in the CESS when possible, not in the 4 foot which is the running line itself.
true-false.imageAlt: Person walking in cess area beside tracks

true-false.statement: If you are caught between adjacent lines when a train approaches, you should lay face down in the 4 foot.
true-false.explanation: This statement is false. If caught between lines, you should lay face down in the 6 foot, 10 foot or CESS, but NEVER in the 4 foot (running line).
true-false.imageAlt: Illustration of correct position between tracks

true-false.statement: A COSS wears a blue armband with white lettering.
true-false.explanation: This statement is true. A Controller of Site Safety (COSS) is identified by their BLUE ARMBAND with COSS written in WHITE LETTERS.
true-false.imageAlt: COSS with blue armband

true-false.statement: The minimum safe distance from Overhead Line Equipment (OHL) is 1 meter.
true-false.explanation: This statement is false. The minimum safe distance from OHL is 2.75 meters (9 foot).
true-false.imageAlt: Safety distance from OHL illustration

true-false.statement: OHL carries 25,000 volts AC and should always be considered live.
true-false.explanation: This statement is true. OHL carries 25,000 volts AC and must be considered live at all times for safety.
true-false.imageAlt: OHL warning sign

true-false.statement: After an OHL tripping, there is a 5-minute delay before re-energisation.
true-false.explanation: This statement is false. After an OHL tripping, the system will try to re-energise IMMEDIATELY.
true-false.imageAlt: OHL re-energisation warning sign

true-false.statement: When crossing a line, it's acceptable to step on rails and sleepers if necessary.
true-false.explanation: This statement is false. When crossing a line, you should walk ballast to ballast and avoid stepping on sleepers, rails, or points.
true-false.imageAlt: Proper track crossing technique

true-false.statement: You can use a mobile phone on the operational railway in an emergency if no other communication is available.
true-false.explanation: This statement is true. You can use a mobile phone in an emergency if no other communication is available, but you must stay in a position of safety and not become distracted.
true-false.imageAlt: Railway worker using mobile phone in position of safety

true-false.statement: Trains always approach from the direction they are signalled.
true-false.explanation: This statement is false. Trains could be making a wrong direction move, operating under Single line working, be a runaway train, or an engineering train in a possession.
true-false.imageAlt: Train moving in unexpected direction

true-false.statement: When protecting the line because of collapsed OHL, detonators can be placed on any line.
true-false.explanation: This statement is false. If any OHL is touching rails, they could be live. Do not place detonators or track circuit clips on any lines you believe may be in contact with OHL.
true-false.imageAlt: Fallen OHL on tracks with warning signs

true-false.statement: The voltage of OHL is 25,000 volts DC.
true-false.explanation: This statement is false. OHL voltage is 25,000 volts AC, not DC.
true-false.imageAlt: OHL warning sign showing AC voltage

true-false.statement: After an OHL tripping, there will be a 5-minute wait before re-energisation.
true-false.explanation: This statement is false. After an OHL tripping, the system will try to re-energise IMMEDIATELY.
true-false.imageAlt: OHL re-energisation warning notice

true-false.statement: A COSS wears a white armband with blue lettering.
true-false.explanation: This statement is false. A COSS (Controller of Site Safety) wears a BLUE armband with WHITE lettering.
true-false.imageAlt: COSS with correct blue armband and white lettering

true-false.statement: When granted an emergency isolation, you can leave once your relief arrives without formally handing over.
true-false.explanation: This statement is false. When granted an emergency isolation and your relief arrives, you must contact the ECO, state who you are and that your relief has arrived, pass the phone to your relief, and DO NOT LEAVE before you are officially relieved.
true-false.imageAlt: Proper handover procedure for isolation duty

true-false.statement: The principles of Red Zone working involve trains still running with a Lookout providing protection.
true-false.explanation: This statement is true. In Red Zone working, trains are still running and a COSS will appoint a 'Lookout' to watch for trains approaching the work area.
true-false.imageAlt: Red Zone working with Lookout

true-false.statement: If crossing a line at a level crossing with gates open to road traffic, it's safe to assume no train is approaching.
true-false.explanation: This statement is false. Never assume no train is approaching, even if level crossing gates are open to road traffic. Barriers could be faulty, a train could have had a SPAD, or it could be a runaway train.
true-false.imageAlt: Level crossing with open barriers but train approaching

true-false.statement: A blue and white square sign means there is no position of safety anywhere in the vicinity.
true-false.explanation: This statement is false. A blue and white square sign with 'warning no refuges' means there is no position of safety for the length of this structure, however, there ARE positions of safety or refuges ON THE OPPOSITE SIDE of the railway line.
true-false.imageAlt: Blue and white no refuges warning sign

true-false.statement: The correct position of safety for speeds of 110mph is 1.25 meters (4 foot) from the nearest running line.
true-false.explanation: This statement is false. The position of safety for speeds of 110mph is 2 meters (6 foot 6 inches), as this applies for speeds between 101-125mph.
true-false.imageAlt: Position of safety distances diagram

true-false.statement: When using a signal post telephone with a red/white limited clearance sign, you should use your train as protection.
true-false.explanation: This statement is true. When using a signal post telephone with a red/white limited clearance sign, you should use your train as protection due to the limited clearance.
true-false.imageAlt: Signal post telephone with limited clearance sign

true-false.statement: Phones with a yellow circle can be used at any time for routine communications.
true-false.explanation: This statement is false. Phones with a yellow circle should only be used in an emergency.
true-false.imageAlt: Telephone with yellow circle marking

true-false.statement: If you sighted a trespasser on the railway, you should always try to stop them yourself before reporting.
true-false.explanation: This statement is false. If you sight a trespasser on the railway, report it immediately to the signaller. If on running lines, make an emergency group call.
true-false.imageAlt: Reporting procedure for trespassers

true-false.statement: A Green Zone 'Separated' arrangement requires at least 6 feet 6 inches between the site of work and the nearest running line.
true-false.explanation: This statement is true. A Green Zone 'Separated' arrangement requires at least 6 feet 6 inches (2 meters) between the site of work and the nearest running line, with a Site Warden appointed by the COSS/SWL to act as a human barrier.
true-false.imageAlt: Green Zone Separated arrangement with measurements

time-trial.definition: On the line itself or within 3 meters (10 foot) of the running line with no fences or permanent structures between you and the running line
time-trial.imageAlt: Illustration of 'on or near the line' zone

time-trial.definition: At least the minimum required distance away from the passing train at the maximum line speed it is permitted to travel

0-100mph: 1.25m (4ft); 101-125mph: 2m (6ft 6in); Over 125mph: no safe distance
